2D perovskite structure presents greater tunability at the
molecular level. To date, a large number of 2D perovskite
absorbers have been synthesized with significantly improved eff
iciencies.
Sargentâs group reported a PCE of 15.3% for
quasiÂ­perovskite PEA
(CH
NH
n
Pb
n
I
n
n
60). It shows
an excellent stability with the efficiency remaining at about
13% after 2 weeks in a humid environment, while the efficiency
of 3D MAPbI
perovskite decreases from 16.6% to 4.3% in
3 days.
(BA)
(MA)
PbI
Â­based solar cell with PCE of 4.02%
was obtained by Cao et al.
Although the introduction of BA
organic cation promotes resistance to moisture more than the
3D counterparts, it also causes outÂ­ofÂ­plane charge transport
inhibition. Notably, Tsai et al. overcame this disadvantage and
achieved a vertical orientation of perovskite layers to the subÂ­
strate by means of a hotÂ­casting deposition method. From the
synchronous diffraction data, the main growth direction of
perovskite is along (101) plane parallel to the
q
z
direction. This
unique orientation enables the photogenerated electrons and
holes to move along the inorganic layer to the deviceâs elecÂ­
trodes, respectively, avoiding the inhibition of organic layers.
Such an efficient charge transport results in a PCE of 12.5% for
(BA)
(MA)
Pb
I
absorber solar cells.
The introduction of 2D RPPs into 3D perovskites has been
proved to guarantee a high efficiency and improved stability
of the solar cells.
For example, Liuâs group reported a
high PCE of 20.62% for 2D/3D heterostructure solar cells.
The devices demonstrated significant longÂ­term ambient staÂ­
bility and worked for more than 2880 h when the efficiency
dropped to 80% of the initial value without encapsulation.
The introduction of BA changes the crystallization kinetics
and controls the morphology of the film, resulting in larger
particle size and improved film quality. The highest PCE
22%) for 2D/3D perovskite solar cell was achieved by GrÃ¤tÂ­
zelâs group, and the solar cells showed remarkable stability
with 90% efficiency of 1000 h in moist air under simulated
sunlight. The excellent performance comes from the forÂ­
mation of ultrathin, ultraÂ­hydrophobic, and highly uniform
2D (FEA)
PbI
(FEA
phenylethylammonium) perovskite
film casted on the 3D perovskite layer. The incorporation
of (FEA)
PbI
not only protects FAPbI
film from the influÂ­
ence of moisture due to its hydrophobicity of fluoroarene,
but also promotes the hole transfer from perovskite layer to
spiroÂ­OMeTAD.
Although 2D perovskite solar cells are at their startÂ­up stage,
and the dielectric and quantum confinement effect plus carrier
transport limit the PCE, they present excellent environmental
stability far beyond 3D perovskites because of their unique layÂ­
ered structure. So, 2D perovskites lay the foundation for 2D/3D
hybrid optoelectronic devices and will have a great potential for
the solar cell commercialization.
5. Summary and Outlook
2D RuddlesdenâPopper perovskites have received wideÂ­
spread attention as promising materials for optoelectronic
devices especially in recent years, due to their unique propÂ­
erties of large exciton binding energy, strong quantum
confinement effect, and stability. Here, we reviewed the
stateÂ­ofÂ­theÂ­art 2D perovskites, with their synthesis methods
for powders and thin films, including singleÂ­crystal growth,
colloidal synthesis, spin coating, and vaporÂ­phase deposition,
and analyzed the possible growth kinetics, various properties
in optoelectronic devices, and applications in LEDs and solar
cells.
QuasiÂ­2D perovskites have larger exciton binding energy,
which is more conducive to radiative recombination. The EQE
of LEDs based on quasiÂ­2D perovskites has reached 20.1%
in nearÂ­infrared emission, 15.5% in green light emission,
and 6.2% in blue light emission. In order to achieve higher
EQE and more stable LEDs, a few immediate issues need to
be addressed. 1) The phase impurity and lowÂ­temperature
solution method for quasiÂ­2D perovskites often increase the
defect density. So, the precise regulation of components and
improvement of film quality are needed. 2) The poor transÂ­
portation of charges in the organic amine spacing layers and
the charge trapping in a surface trap limit the charge injection
and reduce EQE. 3) The equilibrium between mobility and
exciton binding energy should be further optimized for effecÂ­
tive LEDs. Therefore, the design of heterostructures and effiÂ­
cient charge transfer channels are worth studying for quasiÂ­
2D perovskites.
The solar cells based on 2D layered perovskites have demonÂ­
strated excellent PCE and superior stability. The highest PCE
of 2D/3D perovskites has been over 22% and it can be mainÂ­
tained in humid air for more than 1000 h under simulated sunÂ­
light, while PCE has fallen by only 10%. It offers a route toward
efficient and stable perovskite solar cells. However, there are
still some problems to be solved before commercialization. 1)
More efforts need to be made to fully understand their crystal
growth mechanism and to further improve the quality and
morphology of the films. 2) Similarly, the defects caused by the
phase impurity of 2D perovskites will capture the charges and
lead to nonradiative recombination, thus inhibiting the charge
extraction. So, strictly following the stoichiometric ratio of the
reaction to precisely control the value of
n
is desired. 3) In order
to improve the charge transfer process in devices, thin films
with outÂ­ofÂ­plane orientation are desired and the technique of
preparing controllable vertically oriented thin films needs to be
improved. 4) LeadÂ­free perovskites have not yet achieved comÂ­
petitive device efficiencies, and their stability also needs to be
improved.
